ud6.4:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud6.4:1.3: Now at that time several ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers who followed various other paths were residing in Sāvatthī, holding different views and opinions, relying on different views.
ud6.4:2.1: There were some ascetics and brahmins who had this doctrine and view:
ud6.4:2.2: “The world is eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.”
ud6.4:3.1: Others held views such as the following, each regarding their own view as true and others as silly.
ud6.4:6.2: “The soul and the body are the same thing.”
ud6.4:7.2: “The soul and the body are different things.”
ud6.4:9.2: “A Realized One doesn’t exist after death.”
ud6.4:10.2: “A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death.”
ud6.4:11.2: “A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death.”
ud6.4:12.1: They were arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
ud6.4:12.3: That’s not Truth! This is Truth!”
ud6.4:13.1: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ud6.4:13.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening. The Buddha said:
ud6.4:16.1: “The wanderers who follow other paths are blind and sightless.
ud6.4:16.2: They don't understand what is beneficial or what is not beneficial, nor what is the truth and what is not the truth.
